title: What's a scary fact you know about the ocean? : r/AskReddit
body: From what I understand it's not about the changing density of the water, but rather about compression of the air in your lungs. Basically, when you freedive (diving without a tank or external air supply) as you go deeper the water pressure compresses you a little bit, and the most compressible part of you is the air in your lungs.
readable_content:
- Yamper33 (2021-12-19): What's a scary fact you know about the ocean?

    - Applesintheorchard: the Corryvreckan Maelstrom in Scotland is a permanent whirlpool that is the third strongest in the world. It can produce 15 feet high standing waves.

    - TheDodoRexYT: If you pass a certain level underwater, you can no longer float to the surface. You have to use all your strength to swim back up, which can use up too much oxygen and suffocate.

        - ZippyTwoShoes: 40 feet I think then you just sink

    - Stormcell74: Not scary but the Pacific is that deep that it hides most of the worlds tallest Mountain
